Award.AbstractNarration:
University of Rhode Island proposes to support technical services on R/V Endeavor, a 184? general purpose research vessel operated as part of the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System research fleet. The proposal requests support for basic services. They will provide one shipboard technician on each cruise of R/V Endeavor to support seagoing research projects and to maintain, calibrate and provide for qualified users items from their pool of shared-use research instrumentation.

Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under criterion two, providing infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The support of maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mission of the URI Marine Technical Services group is to enhance the scientific productivity of research programs using the R/V Endeavor. To this end, we have provided a robust, modern, general purpose technical infrastructure from which to base research efforts at sea. In addition, each researcher using Endeavor has received technical support, tailored to his or her specific project, which began well in advance of the cruise and continues during and after the cruise. Individually tailored and comprehensive technical support for each research program results in the most effective use of the R/V Endeavor.

The URI Marine Technical support group has both shore based and sea going components. At sea, the Marine Technicians work closely with embarked researchers and facilitate the use of ship’s equipment and interactions with the ship’s officers and crew. The technicians are the interface through which researchers access the capabilities of the vessel. The technicians directly operate and/or assist researchers with ship and shared-use equipment and have the skills and background to make repairs when necessary. Most importantly, the technicians provide a framework of usage, quality assurance and routine maintenance that provides a consistently excellent data product and greatly reduces down time and the need for repairs. Ashore, the Technical Services group performs the varied duties such as maintenance,
calibration, repairs and logistical support that are the foundation of a successful at-sea technical infrastructure.


Last Modified: 04/01/2019
Modified by: William L Fanning
